title: 105_hr4705
content: The Act may be cited as the "Department of Veterans Affairs Employment Reduction Assistance Act of 1998". The term "employee" under the Department of Veterans Affairs Employment Reduction Assistance Act of 1998 refers to a Department of Veterans Affairs employee with at least 3 years of continuous service, excluding reemployed annuitants or employees eligible for disability retirement. Employees eligible for retirement system, involuntary separation for misconduct, previous voluntary separation payment, statutory reemployment rights, transfer to another organization, recruitment or relocation bonus within 24 months. Employees eligible for retirement system, involuntary separation for misconduct, previous voluntary separation payment, statutory reemployment rights, transfer to another organization, recruitment or relocation bonus within 24 months. The term "Department" refers to the Department of Veterans Affairs, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. SEC. 3. DEPARTMENT PLANS; APPROVAL. Before implementing voluntary separation incentive payments, the Secretary must submit a strategic plan to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget outlining the use of such payments and a proposed organizational chart for the Department post-payments. The plan must detail the positions and functions to be reduced or eliminated by organizational unit, geographic location, occupational category, and grade level. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must approve or disapprove each plan submitted by the Secretary for voluntary separation incentives. Modifications may be made to the plan regarding the time period, number and amounts of incentive payments, and coverage based on specified factors. SEC. 4. VOLUNTARY SEPARATION INCENTIVE PAYMENTS. The Secretary may provide voluntary separation incentive payments to reduce positions and functions as per the strategic plan. Employees must voluntarily separate to receive the payment, which is a lump sum after separation and is based on a specific calculation. The Secretary may provide voluntary separation incentive payments to employees who voluntarily separate, based on a specific calculation. The payment amount may not exceed $25,000 and will not affect other government benefits or severance pay entitlements. SEC. 5. EFFECT OF SUBSEQUENT EMPLOYMENT WITH THE GOVERNMENT. An individual who receives a voluntary separation incentive payment under this Act and then accepts government employment within five years must repay the entire incentive amount. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management can waive this repayment requirement for individuals with unique abilities who are the only qualified applicants for certain government positions. An individual who receives a voluntary separation incentive payment under this Act and then accepts government employment within five years must repay the entire incentive amount. The repayment requirement can be waived for individuals with unique abilities who are the only qualified applicants for certain government positions in the legislative or judicial branch. Employment without compensation and through personal services contracts with any government agency are included in the regulations. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL AGENCY CONTRIBUTION TO RETIREMENT FUND. The Secretary must remit 15 percent of the final basic pay of Department employees receiving a voluntary separation incentive to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. "Final basic pay" refers to the total basic pay for a year of service based on the employee's final rate of pay. SEC. 7. REDUCTION OF AGENCY EMPLOYMENT LEVELS. The Department's full-time equivalent employment is reduced by one for each employee who receives a voluntary separation incentive payment. The President will monitor and enforce compliance with this requirement, with waiver authority in cases of war or national emergency. In cases of an extraordinary emergency threatening life, health, safety, property, or the environment, action may be required. SEC. 8. CONTINUED HEALTH INSURANCE COVERAGE. Section 8905a(d)(4) of title 5, United States Code is amended to include provisions for involuntary separation from the Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Defense. This applies to individuals whose coverage is based on separation dates after the enactment of this amendment. Individuals separated from the Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Defense must have specific notice before October 1, 2004, or February 1, 2005. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management may prescribe regulations to administer the provisions of this Act. No voluntary separation incentive may be paid after September 30, 2004. This Act supplements other authority of the Secretary and takes effect upon enactment.
